issuetype.description: A problem which impairs or prevents the functions of the product.
issuetype.name: Bug

resolution.description: The product is working as designed.
resolution.name: Not a Bug

fields.summary: physical core/memory overriding logic produces an incorrect warning

status.description: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are closed can be reopened.
status.name: Closed

issuetype.description: A problem which impairs or prevents the functions of the product.
issuetype.name: Bug

status.description: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are closed can be reopened.
status.name: Closed

fields.summary: MAX_MEM and MAX_CORES in eucalyptus.conf have no real effect

comments.body:
I have this euca support article by Lester Wade in mind:
https://support.eucalyptus.com/hc/en-us/articles/201549604-Overcommiting-CPU-and-Memory-on-Node-Controllers

and I'm running both versions 3.4.2 and 4.0.2 in a all-in-one-box scenario incl NC on _one_ physical machine (I'm aware ... not recommended setup for PROD).

Without making any changes to eucalyptus.conf logfile nc.log report the correct amount of RAM and the correct # of cores.

With changes in eucalyptus.conf I see and expect a WARN in nc.log telling me that the actual number / amount is higher than the ones physically available - expected and OK.
A bit weird is that these warnings report the physically correct amount incorrectly, e.g. number of phys cores = 0 (unexpected) while it was correctly reported before without mods in eucalyptus.conf.

Example:
2015-01-12 22:26:43  WARN | MAX_CORES value is set to 16 that is greater than the amount of physical cores: 0
--> correct value of physical cores here should be 4

nc.log reports then:
2015-01-12 22:26:43  INFO | physical memory available for instances: 32769MB
2015-01-12 22:26:43  INFO | virtual cpu cores available for instances: 16

But this has _no_ effect to the system

 euca-describe-availability-zones verbose
shows exactly the same "free / max" values as if there were no modifications made to eucalyptus.conf - and the system acts accordingly (does not start any new images when all available ressources have been used up)

I'm aware that
 euca-describe-availability-zones verbose
has other delimiting factors as well - e.g. diskspace - but I double-checked already to "cache" and "work" are pointing to a huge empty disk partition (900GB free). Server has 32GB RAM on a minimal centOS 6.6 with only euca 4.0.2 installed.

Even more painful ... there is already an effective discount on available system ressources by 2 cores - which means that on an i5 system (4 cores) 
 euca-describe-availability-zones verbose
reports only 2 available CPUs - and respective low number of images I can start still - and on an i7 server I do see only 6 cores instead of 8 (as reported in nc.log)

repro setup:
a.) minimal centos 6.6
b.) euca 3.4.2 or 4.0.2
c.) all-in-a-single-box incl NC
d.) euca-describe-availability-zones verbose
count two less CPU as reported as available in nc.log
e.) any modifications on MAX_CORES or MAM_MEM in /etc/eucalyptus/eucalyptus.conf will show no effect for [d.] above

I assume the discount (reservation) of 2 CPU on an euca controller is probably intended - and very useful or even necessary on PROD setups to ensure fast response time on the various euca services. 
1.)
However, there should be a (documented) property to switch this off for all-in-one-box installations 
2.) when setting MEM or CORES overcommit in eucalyptus.conf the warning should still report the correct physically detected values (as reported without overcommit)
3.) the overcommit should have effect to 
euca-describe-availability-zones verbose
and the system should allow to start images according to the overcommitted resources (knowing that this is only useful for test setups where instances have (very) low CPU consumption)
Can you turn up the LOG_LEVEL in eucalyptus.conf on an NC and post the doDescribeResources message?

LOG_LEVEL = debug
MAX_CORES = 16

phys CPU = i5-2500K, RAM = 32GB, disk instances work / cache = 900 GB free

output do DescribeRessources:
[root@cl125 ~]# grep doDescribeRes /var/log/eucalyptus/nc.log

[root@cl125 ~]#

Hey [~acmattheis@gmx.net], 

Thanks for the quick response. From the output I can see that you are limited by disk: disk=13/13

If you added disk to the instances directory after starting it the first time, youll need to clear out the the dir and restart the NC or set NC_WORK_SIZE and NC_CACHE_SIZE manually and restart the NC.

Victor, you are completely right - I changed / added in /etc/eucalyptus/eucalyptus.conf

MAX_CORES="16"
NC_WORK_SIZE="300000"
NC_CACHE_SIZE="300000"

and restarted the NC - doDescribeResources is now:
2015-01-13 22:57:14 DEBUG 000006920 doDescribeResource       | Core status:   in-use 0 physical 4 over-committed no
2015-01-13 22:57:14 DEBUG 000006920 doDescribeResource       | Memory status: in-use 0 physical 32769 over-committed no
2015-01-13 22:57:14 DEBUG 000006920 doDescribeResource       | returning status=enabled cores=16/16 mem=32769/32769 disk=287/287 iqn=iqn.1994-05.com.redhat:ce683743d1a6

and then also 
 euca-describe-availability-zones verbose
is now as expected:
[root@cl125 ~]# euca-describe-availability-zones verbose
AVAILABILITYZONE	default	172.29.12.125 arn:euca:eucalyptus:default:cluster:default-cc-1/	
AVAILABILITYZONE	|- vm types	free / max   cpu   ram  disk	
AVAILABILITYZONE	|- m1.small	0016 / 0016   1    256     5	
AVAILABILITYZONE	|- t1.micro	0016 / 0016   1    256     5	
AVAILABILITYZONE	|- m1.medium	0016 / 0016   1    512    10	
AVAILABILITYZONE	|- c1.medium	0008 / 0008   2    512    10	
AVAILABILITYZONE	|- m1.large	0008 / 0008   2    512    10	
AVAILABILITYZONE	|- m1.xlarge	0008 / 0008   2   1024    10	
AVAILABILITYZONE	|- c1.xlarge	0008 / 0008   2   2048    10	
AVAILABILITYZONE	|- m2.xlarge	0008 / 0008   2   2048    10	
AVAILABILITYZONE	|- m3.xlarge	0004 / 0004   4   2048    15	
AVAILABILITYZONE	|- m2.2xlarge	0008 / 0008   2   4096    30	
AVAILABILITYZONE	|- m3.2xlarge	0004 / 0004   4   4096    30	
AVAILABILITYZONE	|- cc1.4xlarge	0002 / 0002   8   3072    60	
AVAILABILITYZONE	|- m2.4xlarge	0002 / 0002   8   4096    60	
AVAILABILITYZONE	|- hi1.4xlarge	0002 / 0002   8   6144   120	
AVAILABILITYZONE	|- cc2.8xlarge	0001 / 0001  16   6144   120	
AVAILABILITYZONE	|- cg1.4xlarge	0001 / 0001  16   12288   200	
AVAILABILITYZONE	|- cr1.8xlarge	0001 / 0001  16   16384   240	
AVAILABILITYZONE	|- hs1.8xlarge	0000 / 0000  48   119808  24000	

So I confirm this is no bug - this is a user (me) unable to read / understand the documentation "admin_guide" 

There is a tiny thing left - in case a user overrides the "cores" or "mem" then the WARN output message is incorrect in showing the real physical value - you may want to look into this, still - from a quick view into the source code it appears to me the number format is still %d instead of %lld what it should be (just an educated guess)

Hey, [~acmattheis@gmx.net], thanks for the follow up and for pointing out a nonsensical WARN. I created EUCA-10356 to track that problem (we'll get to it in 4.1.1, probably) and will close this ticket as not-a-bug. Cheers!
